label: Sloth bear
description: <p>The shaggy-coated sloth bear is native to India, Sri Lanka and Nepal. Sloth bears primarily eat termites and ants, and unlike other bear species, they routinely carry their cubs on their backs.</p>

label: Asian small-clawed otter
description: <p>Asian small-clawed otters are the smallest of all 13 otter species and are native to Asia. Well adapted to life in the water, these social, intelligent animals spend a majority of their time on land.</p>

label: American bison
description: <p>The largest terrestrial animals in North America, bison once roamed in herds numbering in the millions dominating prairie and forest ecosystems. Now reduced to a fraction of their current range and population, bison survive mainly in conservation herds.</p>

label: Fishing cat
description: <p>Fishing cats are native to southern Asia. Very little is known about the behavior, habitat, population and habits of these elusive, nocturnal felines.</p>

label: Japanese giant salamander
description: <p>Japanese giant salamanders are the second-largest salamander species in the world. These long-lived amphibians lurk in Japan's rocky, fast-flowing streams.</p>

label: Allen's swamp monkey
description: <p>Allen's swamp monkeys are small, stout monkeys with brown to gray fur and long tails. These highly social primates live in central Africa's swamp forests where they spend most of their time in trees. They are often hunted for bushmeat, killed in retaliation for crop raids and captured for the pet trade.</p>

label: Black-and-white ruffed lemur
description: <p>Black-and-white ruffed lemurs and red-ruffed lemurs are the largest in their family. Active during the day, and living mainly in trees, they are native only the Madagascar and critically endangered.</p>

label: Land hermit crab
description: <p>Land hermit crabs live close to the shoreline and must have access to both land and water. They are popular pets but do not breed in human care. Consequently, the pet trade harvests them from the wild, which is unsustainable.</p>

label: Norway rat
description: <p>The brown rat prefers to live almost anywhere humans are. Rats are foragers that can survive on a huge range of foods, which has helped them spread so successfully across the world. Humans often dislike rats, but rats present a variety of benefits to their ecosystems as predator and prey, are popular pets and have contributed to advances in the fields of genetics, cognitive research, physiology, epidemiology and pathology.</p>

label: Red-fronted lemur
description: <p>Red-fronted lemurs are tree-dwelling animals about the size of a house cat. They live in Madagascar's deciduous forests and primarily eat fruit and leaves.</p>

label: Ring-tailed lemur
description: <p>Ring-tailed lemurs are named for the 13 alternating black and white bands that adorn their tails. Unlike most other lemurs, ringtails spend 40 percent of their time on the ground, moving quadrupedally along the forest floor.</p>

label: Schmidt's red-tailed monkey
description: <p>The Schmidt’s red-tailed monkey — also called the black-cheeked white-nosed monkey, red-tailed guenon or Schmidt's guenon — is a small guenon characterized by a distinctive white or yellow nose, white cheeks and a long, red tail. These monkeys are native to central Africa and are threatened by hunting and deforestation. <span> </span></p>

label: Western lowland gorilla
description: <p>Gorillas are the largest of the great apes, but the western lowland gorilla is the smallest of the subspecies. Native to the Congo Basin, the western lowland gorilla is a quiet, peaceful and nonaggressive animal threatened by disease and poaching.</p>

label: Andean bear
description: The Andean bear, or spectacled bear, is the only bear native to South America. It is a clever, arboreal animal that builds platforms and nests in trees for eating and sleeping.

label: Brown pelican
description: <p>A beautiful and unexpectedly graceful bird, brown pelicans live along both coasts of North America. Once threatened by DDT, they were one of the first species to recover from the effects of the pesticide and be removed from the Endangered Species List.</p>

label: Bald eagle
description: <p>The bald eagle, the United States' national symbol, plummeted from abundance to endangered status; only 417 pairs were left in 1963. Thanks to tireless conservation efforts, this fish-eating raptor has rebounded and been removed from the Endangered Species List.</p>

label: Siamang
description: <p>Siamangs are arboreal inhabitants of the Malay Peninsula and Sumatran rain and monsoon forests. Their distinguishing feature is a large throat sac that they use to make socially important vocalizations. These primates are endangered due to illegal pet trade and habitat loss.</p>

label: White-cheeked gibbon
description: <p>Gibbons live in the evergreen tropical rainforests and monsoon forests of Laos, Vietnam and southern China. They are arboreal and spend most of their time in the forest canopy. White-cheeked gibbons are critically endangered, and their numbers have declined by 80 percent or more over the past 45 years, primarily due to habitat loss and poaching.</p>

label: Beaver
description: <p>Beavers are the largest rodents in North America and one of the few species that significantly modify their environment. By building watertight dams, which reduce stream erosion and form slow-moving ponds, they provide aquatic habitat for dozens of other species.</p>

label: Gray wolf
description: <p>Also called the timber wolf, gray wolves are the largest members of the canine family. Devoted parents and families, they are also among the most social carnivores. Once possessed of the greatest range of any terrestrial mammals except humans, they are now restricted in North America mainly to Alaska, Canada and wilderness in the northern United States.</p>

label: California sea lion
description: <p>Sea lions are large, gregarious mammals found along the western coast of North America. In the water, their torpedo-shaped bodies can reach speeds of 25 to 30 mph (40 to 48 kph).</p>

label: Gray seal
description: Gray seals, also called <span>horsehead</span> seals, are amazingly dexterous swimmers. They are common on both sides of the north Atlantic.

label: Harbor seal
description: <p>Harbor seals, also known as common seals, spend half their time in the sea and half on land. They have the widest distribution of any seal and live in both the North Atlantic and Northern Pacific oceans. Harbor seals can be found anywhere from cool, temperate waters to cold, arctic and sub-arctic coasts.</p>

label: North American river otter
description: <p>The North American river otter is the most abundant otter species, but surprisingly little is known about its life in the wild. These otters are frequently observed playing and sliding together.<span> </span></p>

label: Hooded merganser
description: Hooded mergansers are ducks named for the white, fanlike crests that males have on their heads. These birds are the smallest North American mergansers. They breed in Canada and spend winters along coastal regions in the U.S.

label: Common raven
description: <p>Remarkably intelligent and social animals, ravens have been documented using tools. These omnivorous aerial acrobats range across much of the globe.</p>

label: Aldabra tortoise
description: <p>One of the world's largest land tortoises, Aldabra tortoises can reach sizes of up to 550 pounds and ages of up to 150 years old. They are native to Aldabra Island, one of the Seychelles northeast of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean.</p>

label: American alligator
description: <p>Similar in appearance to the endangered American crocodile, alligators are not endangered. They range along waterways in the United States from North Carolina to Texas's Rio Grande.</p>

label: Burmese rock python
description: <p>The largest subspecies of the Indian python, and one of the largest snakes in the world, Burmese pythons range throughout southeast Asia.</p>

label: Chinese alligator
description: <p>A critically endangered cousin of the American alligator, it is one of the few alligators outside of the Americas. It is native to slow-moving freshwater areas of the lower Yangtze River in China where it eats snails, crustaceans, insects, fish, young waterfowl and rodents.</p>

label: Cuban crocodile
description: <p>One of the most endangered species of crocodile, the Cuban crocodile is now found only in a limited range in Cuba.</p>

label: Eastern indigo snake
description: <p>Eastern indigo snakes are one of the largest North American snakes, reaching lengths of 5-7 feet. They are nonvenomous and found across the southeastern United States.</p>

label: Eastern red-backed salamander
description: <p>Lungless, eastern red-backed salamanders need to live in damp or moist habitats to breathe. They are native to the eastern United States and Canada.</p>

label: Eyelash palm pitviper
description: <p>One of the smallest venomous snakes in Central America, the eyelash palm pitviper is named for the bristly scales above its eyes.</p>

label: Gaboon viper
description: <p>The largest vipers in Africa, Gaboon vipers are lethargic and placid-natured. They only very rarely bite humans.</p>

label: Gharial
description: The critically endangered <span>gharial</span> is easily distinguished from other crocodiles, because of the long, slender snout it shares only with the tomistoma (previously called the false gharial).

label: Gila monster
description: <p>Not monsters at all, Gila monsters are one of the few species of venomous lizards on the planet. These carnivores are classified as near threatened, and they are native to Arizona, California and Mexico.</p>

label: Green anaconda
description: Green anacondas are one of the largest snakes in the world. Reports of anaconda attacks on humans are rare, but these boas can take down large prey, including jaguars.

label: Green salamander
description: Green salamanders live predominantly in wet, damp crevices and are the only salamander of the genus <span>Aneides</span> found in the eastern United States.

label: Green tree python
description: <p>Green tree pythons are named for their vibrant green color. These nonvenomous snakes and found in the tropical rainforests of New Guinea, eastern Indonesia, and the northeast Cape York Peninsula of Australia.</p>

label: Hellbender
description: <p>The eastern hellbender is the Americas’ largest salamander. Living in clean, swift-running rivers across the eastern United States, they spend their entire lives in the water. This near-threatened species is protected in several states.</p>

label: King cobra
description:
King cobras are impressively venomous, large snakes native to Asia. They are called king cobras because they can kill and eat cobras.
<p> <!--EndFragment--></p>

label: Komodo dragon
description: <p>Komodo dragons, or Komodo monitors, are the largest, heaviest lizards in the world — and one of the few with a venomous bite. These stealthy, powerful hunters rely on their sense of smell to detect food, using their long, forked tongues to sample the air. They can spend hours waiting for a sizable meal to wander within range before launching a deadly attack with their large, curved and serrated teeth.</p>

label: Long-tailed salamander
description: True to its name, the long-tailed salamander's tail takes up more than half of its body length. These salamanders are found along the eastern United States where they live in creek beds, caves, streams and ponds.

label: Painted river terrapin
description: <p>Dull in appearance for most of the year, painted terrapins actually get their name from their coloration during the breeding season when they acquire a vivid red stripe on their heads. Painted terrapins are critically endangered and native to the fresh and brackish waters of Southeast Asia.</p>

label: Northern copperhead
description: The northern copperhead is a large, social, venomous snake found across the eastern United States in terrestrial and semiaquatic habitats.

label: Panamanian golden frog
description: <p>The Panamanian golden frog is a tiny, brightly colored, frog-like toad native to the rainforests and cloud forests of Panama, though it is extinct in the wild. Its bright coloration warns predators of its overwhelming toxicity.</p>

label: Panamanian golden frog
description: <p>The Panamanian golden frog is a tiny, brightly colored, frog-like toad native to the rainforests and cloud forests of Panama, though it is extinct in the wild. Its bright coloration warns predators of its overwhelming toxicity.</p>

label: Red panda
description: <p>Red pandas, like giant pandas, are bamboo eaters native to Asia’s high forests. Despite these similarities and their shared name, the two species are not closely related. Red pandas are much smaller than giant pandas and are the only living member of their taxonomic family.</p>
